description.en:
The lecture course includes blocks of all computational chemistry (theoretical chemistry) areas:
- Digital presentation chemical structures
- Quantum chemistry
- Molecular mechanisc
- Molecular dynamics,
- Cheminformatics
- Etc.
description.et:
Loengukursus sisaldab blokke kõikidest arvutuskeemia (teoreetilise keemia) valdkondadest:
- keemiliste struktuuride digitaalne esitamine, 
- kvantkeemia, 
- molekulaarmehaanika, 
- molekulaardünaamika, 
- keemiainformaatika, 
- jne.

objectives.en: Provide an overview of modern computational chemistry methods in understanding chemical processes and phenomena and to describe the properties of materials.
objectives.et: Anda ülevaade kaasaaegsetest arvutuskeemia meetoditest keemiliste protsesside ja nähtuste ning materjalide omaduste kirjeldamisel.

learning_outcomes.en: The student has knowledge of modern computational chemistry methods for the explaining of chemical processes and phenomena and describing the properties of materials.
learning_outcomes.et: Üliõpilane omab ülevaadet ja teadmisi kaasaegsete arvutuskeemia meetodite rakendamisest keemiliste protsesside ja nähtuste lahtiseletamisel ja materjalide omaduste kirjeldamisel.

notes.et: Description of lecture setup will be in first lecture

description.et: Based on set of questions using following scale: A - 91-100%, B - 81-90%, C - 71-80%, D - 61-70%, E - 51-60%, F - 0-59%.

grade_preconditions.et: Students say that they are ready to take exam, but not later than week before agreed date during meeting with lecturer.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.mandatory_materials:
1. Guy H. Grant, W. Graham Richards, Computational Chemistry (Oxford Chemistry Primers, 29), Oxford University Press, 1995 (reprint 2005).
2. Andrew R. Leach, Molecular Modelling: principles and applications, Prentice Hall, 2001.
3. Andrew R. Leach, Valerie J. Gillet, An Introduction to Chemoinformatics, Springer, 2003/2007.
4. David Livingstone, A Practical Guide to Scientific Data Analysis, Whiley, 2009.

description.et:
(For detailed description of chapters to read from books see separate file under the study materials.)
Introduction
Digital presentation chemical structures 
Quantum mechanics/chemistry (ab initio, semiempirical methods)
Geometry optimization
Molecular mechanics
Molecular Dynamics
Condensed media in computational chemistry
Partial charges and frontier orbital theory
Scientific data and its properties
Data pre-treatment & variable selection
Visualizing data (pattern reconition)
Regression analysis
Unsupervised and supervised learning
Artificial intelligence in chemistry
Molecular descriptors
Molecular fingerprints & Molecular similarity
Virtual screening
